content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-19-A |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the 2 main etiological frameworks of delayed puberty: hypothalamic-pituitary or gonadal origins |Description=None |Rubric=Etiologies |Contributors= |Order=19}} {| class="wikitable" | '''RP centraux''' | |- |Hypothalamo-pituitary                         | Acquired: tumour (craniopharyngioma), functional (malnutrition, chronic illness) Congenital and genetic: hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with (Kallmann) or without anosmia, panhypopituitarism |- | Simple pubertal delay | Variant of normal, diagnosis of elimination |- | | |- | '''Peripheral RP'''' | |- | Ovarian insufficiency Testicular failure | Turner syndrome 45,X Klinefelter syndrome 47,XXY |}

question.title: What are the two main etiological frameworks of delayed puberty?

option_a.title: Hypothalamic-pituitary or gonadal origins
option_a.description: One of the two main etiological frameworks of delayed puberty

option_b.title: Hypothalamic-pituitary or genetic factors
option_b.description: A possible etiological framework of delayed puberty

option_c.title: Gonadal or genetic factors
option_c.description: Another possible etiological framework of delayed puberty

option_d.title: Hormonal or genetic factors
option_d.description: A general term for the etiological frameworks of delayed puberty
